text: my name is Blair Layton I'm the database business development manager for AWS I've actually been working at AWS for
nearly five years and what we're going to be talking about today is managing a database migration project so what I
want to cover off in this session is the first thing is to talk about database migration context so we need to cover
off a few things about what we need to consider then we're going to look at some database migration tools that AWS
has and then introduce the AWS migration framework and this is the guts of what
we need to consider for doing a database migration project and then a little bit on database migration effort and talk
about some customer references and then finally next steps so if we look at the
database migration context what we're going to be talking about here is a couple of things the first one is around
data movement and storage so first of all there's five questions that you
really need to consider when you are doing a migration project the first one is what kind of data is it and where as
it's going so for example if you were moving from a relational database are you going to be going to another relational database or are you even
considering archiving so you could actually take data from a relational database and put that into say s3 one of
our storage services and that can work very well from an archiving perspective also is it going to be a one-time
migration or is it going to be a continuous migration so what I mean by that is that you could be just moving in
a database let's say it's my sequel on-premise to my sequel on ec2 today but
at the same time you may want to actually do that once or twice or maybe continuously and if you want to
continuously then you're gonna have to replicate the data all the time from AWS to on-prem or from on-prem into AWS so
you need to consider you know just how much data you're going to be moving and what type of movement it is so is it
going to be a one-way or bi-directional model as well now there's going to be
bi-directional that gets really complex and you're gonna have to probably use some partner software to solve some of
those problems and the two last points are kind of correlate two one is how much data and time do you
have to do the migration and also the network related to the migration so if
you've got a long period of time then you'll lead less network to push that data through if you've got a short
period of time you're gonna need more network bandwidth to push that data through in that time that you have to do the migration so those are the things
about moving the data around and where to store it and the kind of key questions you need to consider there then you need to make decisions about
what if you're gonna move from a relational database say on Prem are you going to target relational database in
AWS and if you are then you need to make decisions are you going to run that on ec2 which is obviously a computer
platform or in our relational database service engine RDS now on the left-hand
side here we have Amazon Arora and this is our take on an enterprise class
database to give the performance and scalability of the typical commercial databases but at the cost and simplicity
of the open source databases and that is now available in the Singapore region for both flavors on my sequel and
Postgres so you'll find that you'll get superior performance better availability
durability from the Aurora platform then you would by running just the open
source community additions on RDS but if you still prefer to do that then we allow you to do that as well and you can
run that on the RDS platform for my sequel Postgres and marija DB and then
on the commercial side we have oracle database and sequel server that you can run as well so if you're looking to do
relational to relational that's great we've got that option for you as well now if you want to look at doing
relational to know sequel or maybe you have MongoDB or Cassandra and you're considering having a managed service
then dynamodb is the answer for that so this is very very fast highly scalable
no sequel managed service at AWS and we can scale to hundreds of terabytes of
data millions of requests per second and very fast consistent performance so even if
you're reorganizing the throughput that we need to go and allocate different underneath to give you the throughput
that you need the response time remains almost flat so this is very hard to
achieve and it's a really good aspect of this particular database it's also fully managed you don't have to worry about
any infrastructure you simply say create this table and allocate how many reads and writes you would like per second
from that particular table and then we'll take care of everything else when you need more you simply adjust it and
say I would like to say more reads go from 1000 reads per second to 10000 reads per second and will manage all of that behind the scenes as well and it's
business-critical you know ready for these business critical workloads so it's stored in three different
facilities so your data is going to be highly durable and it's designed to be highly available with minimal downtime
it and ideally no downtime at all and in fact it's so critical for us at Amazon
that AWS and amazon.com use DynamoDB extensively so it's a business critical
database for us you can trust it to deliver the goods now if you've decided
on the different data bases that you want to go to then you start thinking how am I going to do this well
traditionally migrations were quite expensive and they're quite complex you
often have to get commercial software sometimes you pay quite a lot of money for that commercial software just to do even a one-off migration and if you
weren't looking at these kind of commercial offerings if you're gonna do it manually you'd have to have quite extensive downtime to do the migration
and then even then it was quite complex to set up and get everything going and you might have had to do you know
database specific code in your applications as you're doing the migrations from one to the other so what
we've come up with is a set of tools to make your life easier to do these database migrations and the first one is
what we call the AWS database migration service now this is a service to help
you move data and I must say there's actually two tools that are very
important that we're going to cover off and this one think of it as moving data it is not about moving the schema or
changing the the table definitions or procedures and things so we have another tool I'm going to talk about to do
those things but you can see down the bottom there the selection of databases most of these are source and targets
some are target only such as Amazon redshift some are source only such as sequel but fundamentally between say
Postgres Oracle my sequel sequel server Amazon Aurora you can move data back and forth between these different databases
so how does it actually work well here you can see on the left hand side that
you've got your on-premise environment today your users are connecting into that on the right hand side we've got a
double us with a VPN connecting that in AWS there's a brand new database it's got the nice empty schema in there it's
got the user definitions the tables and so on but there's no data so what we're doing is we're going to start a
replication instance inside AWS so this is dms running then the next thing we're
going to do is connect up the source and the target once we have the source and the target defined then when you decide
are we going to take tables are we gonna take schemas or the whole database and then once you've decided on that we
start moving the data across and bringing the data as the application is still running on premise so as the data
gets sucked across we then move into what's called change data capture after we've done the bulk transfer and then
that means that any changes that are happening on production are being mirrored across into AWS so then once
this is in this stage you would say okay let's suspend activity on the primary system and then simply flip over to AWS
once it's caught up so that could be seconds it could be a bit longer depending on your network but fundamentally the downtime now to do a
migration is very very low so this is a really important important service the
AWS can scheme a conversion tool is that separate tool that I talked about that actually does the schema changes so it
actually has a few tricks up its sleeve as well it's not just about doing schema changes so the first thing that you
would do is use this tool to actually convert say Oracle to Postgres for
example and that means it would go through the table definitions and the datatypes and then create the equivalent thing in Postgres it'll also go through
PL sequel and then create PL PG sequel on the other side so you'd again the equivalent
and we're able to actually achieve quite good conversion now some cases in the 90 percents for going from Oracle to
Postgres with this particular tool it also allows you to copy a database so let's say you've got an old Oracle
database on-premise and you want to move that into AWS but you don't have the DDL that's defined the schema we can
actually copy the schema for a database when you're moving there as well so that could be Oracle my sequel sequel server
whatever whichever you want to copy you can do that with a schema conversion tool and then on the right hand side
there we've got data warehouse support so what we can do in the data warehouse is is take the source data warehouse and
convert that to Amazon redshift and we also support the unloading of data and
loading of data through the schema conversion tool so this means that we can take data put it into CSV files and
then load that in now if your data warehouses are actually very big so let's say it's more than 50 terabytes and you don't want to transfer that over
the network we also offer integration with snowball so you can actually put huge data
warehouse onto a physical device bring that into AWS we'll load that into s3 and then you'll be able to transfer that
in so we have different mechanisms for large volumes of getting data into AWS as well now the first thing that you
would actually ever do with the schema conversion tool is run this report and what this report is all about is to say
okay how hard is it going to be to do one of these migrations and what you would do is you connect the schema
conversion tool to your source database it's not gonna do any changes or any migration work or anything it's just
going to look at what the database is and then do comparisons from say sequel server or Oracle to my sequel and
Postgres and then tell you the problems that's found how many of those problems it's found and give you an assessment
which you can see from from the graphs on how was the percentage of tables and objects that could be actually migrated
so this is a really great tool to do the assessment of how of the migration and
decide is this even worthwhile because there will be some very complex databases that you would have to think
twice about migrating especially if there's lots of business logic in store procedures and we're not able to easy
convert that now that all depends on the complexity of the code and everything you may have lots of stored procedures
and run the tool and it's absolutely fine so you need to run the tool get an assessment and then decide is this
something that you can actually do so when do you use the database migration
service and the schema conversion tool well there are a couple of different
phases during the migration project on the assessment as we just talked about there is the assessment report from the
schema conversion tool so that's what you would run there on the schema migration where you're going to take the
database definition and move that to the target database that's again what the schema conversion tool is for on the
data migration primarily you're going to use the database migration service but you may use the schema conversion tool
as well because that's going to give you the ability to do their unloading and loading for large datasets on
application migration the schema conversion tool also allows you to look at application code so you could get it
to scan its Java files and then it will look for sequel statements in those Java files and convert them to say from
Oracle sequel to Postgres sequel so you can do application migrations through the schema conversion tool as well data
validation is a new feature of the database migration service and that allows you to then to compare what was
on the source system and what was on the target system and confirmed that that is actually fully migrated and everything
is accurate and then the last two we can't help you out do it directly that's the functional testing and the
performance testing you'll have probably have tools like loadrunner and those types of things that you can actually run yourself and then do those tests as
part of your migration so for the different migration scenarios that was
the different phases of the project on what you would use but for different migration scenarios there's different things that you can do as well so if you
were going to do a homogeneous migration now with the homogeneous migration what we mean is we're staying on the same
database and in this case we're staying on the same addition and version and if you're going to say oh it's so laura
oracle database 11g r2 and we're gonna move that actually exactly as it is into
AWS in that case you don't need to use any of the tooling from our side you could simply use setup data guard you've
already got a license for it built into Oracle Enterprise Edition and then you could just use the native replication the same of
for my sequel Postgres etc you could set up a read replica and failover to that for homogeneous migration to a different
version that becomes more difficult right that's not easy to do with native tools so you would use the database
migration service in the schema conversion tool for that use case and then for a homogeneous migration to a
different Edition so for this case and you want to go from say sequel server Enterprise Edition and save some money and go to sequel server standard edition
then you can use the database migration service and the schema conversion tool for that as well and then finally the
last one which is the traditional heterogeneous migration as for those of you who don't appreciate paying lots of
money to Oracle for example for a database license and support and you say right we've had up with this we're going
to move to open source and that's where you definitely need to do schema conversion using the schema conversion
tool and the data movement with the database migration service so that's the the tools but what about migration
projects right how do you actually do a migration project well what we're going
to talk about is looking at the migration framework that we've came up
with so the AWS migration framework is a slide of you were earlier in the day and
you saw peridot speaking you might have seen this in his presentation here's the idea that you start off with readiness
and planning and starting to assess what you actually have then activate is the next stage where you start to build a
team you do a pilot or a proof of concept and the lessons from that then feed into the execute phase where you
iteratively get better and better at executing on these types of projects and then you optimize as well and then and
optimize you're doing things like you know cost management making sure processes are working correctly doing
all of those things that are going to make your life a lot easier so what we're going to do is go through this in the context of a database
migration so readiness and planning what do we need to do well the first thing is
we need to actually look at how is this going to work for this particular migration project is it a single
application are we doing a fleet are we exiting a data center all of that kind of stuff so the the first thing you need
to do is get an executive sponsor this is really important right I've seen this at many customers where they don't get
the right many I'm involved and people flounder when they try and get the things done in the project just keeps on going because
people are not focused on getting it done or someone from upstairs can't come down and say this is what we're doing
let's go and get it done is there a compelling event that's going to affect the migration strategy you know we have
customers who say right we've got a data center contract it's going to be ended at the end of say July and we've got to
be out no that's compelling you've got to get stuff done by that date so make sure you know if there's any deadlines
or anything like that do you have the right resources it's all very well saying yeah we don't want sequel server
anymore let's go to my sequel but if you don't have any my sequel people it's going to make migration extremely
difficult because you need the people who are experts in the target as well and then do you have the budget it's
going to cost money the stuff is not free unfortunately so we need to look at all of these things and then start
looking at our application environments so if you look looking across your applications and seeing what you have
available you'll probably come in and start to realize that there's some things which are tricky so if you look at the revisit up there it's saying if
you've got a hardware appliance that is not even x86 that's going to be really difficult right that's something maybe
we'll come back and look at that a bit later the eligible one we're talking about something that's already virtualized on x86 it's easy to move and
bring that into AWS friendly is something that can scale horizontally that means you can take advantage of
auto scaling save money when you're not using the application and then expand when the business comes in and you need
to have more servers and then of course cloud native or SAS environment where it's microservices api's and
everything's running wonderfully on the cloud so you can schedule your migration priorities based on these types of
things that you're looking at in your application environment so when you start looking at the overall application
assessment you need to say okay what's the business driver and the intended ROI here you're not going to be able to just
go in from an IT perspective and go hey this is gonna be cool let's just move this application from on pram into AWS
and we'll change the database from sequel server to my sequel that's great you know you've got to go and talk to
the business owner and justify why you want to do that so therefore the business owner has to buy or sea level has to buy in this is
something that you really want to do and you you know I going to get a business benefit from it
is there an ISV application that is part of what you're going to move because if
the ISP is not certified on AWS that's gonna make it really hard to get support and you know you may have to reconsider
what you want to do on that case now if you do have an ISP that's not certified in AWS please always talk to us because
we're more than happy to help those partners migrate their solutions onto AWS as well the maintenance window of the migration
if it is yeah no problem we'll shut down you know 7 p.m. on Friday and you can
have the whole weekend and then Monday at 8 a.m. you need to be backup that's easy right 2 to 4 days and a bit more of
downtime but if the business owner says yeah five minutes that's it well that changes the whole dynamics of the
project and how you're going to manage it is the design documentation there and the original developers or dbaas
because if you don't have design documentation you don't have the original people you're going to be looking through a whole bunch of code
that you don't understand you don't even know if it's relevant which components need to be migrated and which don't exception then when you come to the
database assessment you need to look at well okay how many objects are their tables triggers etc how much data is
there because the volume of data is going to determine how much you need to push across the network and what time period our proprietary database features
used so for example you could be looking at something like an Oracle database
vault yeah it's a specific option there's no equivalent to that in the open source world then in non-standard
or custom data types something like spatial spatial data is not easily mapped from one database to
another at the moment we're working on improving that but for the moment you would have to do that manually and then character set conversions of someone's
using Chinese character set or Hindi character set or something like that then you're going to have to look at the
make a decision do we move to Unicode and then of using local time zones do you use UTC because AWS we use UTC
everywhere then what's the user authentication method and finally and definitely not last is the licensing
mechanism because if you're looking at licensing you've got to understand when you move say sequel server or Oracle or other
commercial software onto AWS how much is that going to cost for you and is that viable for you as well now when you get
to the technical side of the application the most important thing for database migrations is how is the database
accessed in that application so if you've got sequel statements throughout that code you know PHP developers
anywhere probably written code through everything and there's just sequel statements everywhere that's not a good
thing right it's gonna be lots of sequel statements that we need to go and look at and migrate now if you've got an data
abstraction layer or api's that you're calling to manipulate the database that's going to mean that the sequel
statements are going to be in a controlled space that you're gonna have less of them and be able to manage that
much easier if you've used anti sequel then that's going to be great because it's gonna be much easier to migrate
between databases as well and then you need to look at sequel complexity because if you've got an application
which has got tons of reports and these report sequel statements are like pages and pages long the complexity of migrating that is far higher than for an
OLTP database which is just doing basic crud you know short statements to just do inserts updates and deletes and so on
and then overall look at the number of my lines of sequel code and then also how are people accessing the application
from an authentication mechanism now once you understand all of this environment about your applications your
priorities how they integrate you know what's the details of the database and the application for each of these
environments you then have to make decisions about what you're going to do with each of them and we have what we're
calling the six hours of migration planning so the first one is retained that means you're not gonna do anything
you're gonna leave it where it is whether it's on-premise or whether it's on AWS and you we're gonna do a
modernization but you decide no maybe that's going to be retired in another year we're just gonna leave that there
for the moment and then once the years past we're gonna turn it off and you actually see this quite often when
customers go and look at their data centers and they evaluate what's actually in there they do find a number of systems which are not actually being
used and we've had customers who've gone round and you know I started taking out the network ports to say is anyone
complaining because they didn't know who the owner was anymore retire is very common as well because
they find these types of applications that no one's using and then they simply say oh well let's just turn them off we're not gonna use these anymore and
you retire them out of the data center we architect or refactor this is really
something that's quite useful because what you can say is well this application as we move it to the cloud
we're gonna add new features and functionality modernize the architecture maybe add a mobile front end change the
database tier to include caching make it faster and so on so react a texture is very important repurchase if you have an
isp application maybe they have a SAS version available in the cloud already so instead of doing the physical
migration you can just switch to using the SAS version and you just need to work out how to migrate the data across and then on rhe platform that's where
you might say ok this is running on Windows today we're going to move this to Linux and we'd standardize on that and change the operating system or
you're gonna change the database as part of the replac form and then we host is the common one that we refer to as lift
and shift which is basically take it as it is and put it into AWS and do the
minimum amount of work to make that actual application function in the cloud
so those are the six R's very important to remember these different options so once we've done the assessment then we
move on to activate and once we're in activate then you've got to look at how you're going to get your priorities and
put them together with integrated applications right you can take what say I will just do this application but it's integrated with others you're gonna have
to do those as a group more than likely you didn't know what your success criteria is for each of your applications as well and then you've got
to go through and create your team you'll prove the concept and build out how that is all going to work so how do
you build out a team well you need application architects and developers and then you also going to need a source
DBA the person who's probably using your system today and managing your system but you're also gonna need a target DBA
because if you're going to move from one database to another you're not going to be able to ramp up in the skills internally and because you probably
haven't dealt with that database before so you might need to get some skills outside and then an AWS solution architect this doesn't have to be
someone from AWS but somebody who understands AWS and is able to architect the application correctly in the
environment and then of course you need application and database developers to actually do the grunt work because they're gonna have to rewrite the code
they're gonna have to rewrite the database or procedures and those types of things so how do you get the talent
or you're gonna have to hire and develop people into the organization so you you need new skills you're gonna have to
develop training plans for existing employees hire new people in and you
know retain redeploy or unfortunately in some cases make people redundant if those skills are no longer relevant and
they're not willing to take on new responsibilities or learn new things so when you do the pilot or the
proof-of-concept a lot of people do a couple of things they choose the easy
one and they go bus bus we did the migration was so easy we're gonna do
everything really quickly but of course if you did the easy one you didn't really find any challenges and the
opposite happens if you do the hardest one you'll say oh this is impossible we're gonna say on-prem what we want to
do is to choose something in the middle it's reasonably complex you're gonna find out some things which are tricky
and you'll solve those problems but you'll learn a lot from that process so you get more accurate results and you'll
determine what can be automated through that you'll determine what skills are missing you'll learn a lot through this process and by learning a lot then you
can move into the execute phase because now you'll have your applications all understood how they integrate together
and you've learnt your lessons that you can now apply to the execute phase and
of course when you're doing actual migrations always have a back-up plan to be able to get back to where you were
right you don't want to just say yep we'll do the migration today and then it goes wrong in the idea we're in this mid kind of space where nothing's happening
that's a very bad area different options for the cutover if you're looking at
something like a parallel run remember I mentioned that DMS can do a failover from one point to the other point with a
minimal downtime but we don't support parallel run with data being shared against both systems if you want to do
something like that and that's normally like telco banking government in some cases and we have partners like
informatica and others that provide more advanced software to do those types of things minimum or downtime we can definitely do
with DMS and CDC and then if there's a large maintenance window you can do just expose
and import and those types of traditional approaches for doing database migrations so then we get on to
optimize so you've now executed you've done a few projects you've iterated on
that and proved the whole life cycle and now you need to actually say okay this stuff's running let's get this into an
optimal State so here you're gonna be looking at things like if you're running DMS for constant data migration then
what you want to do is to optimize the tasks and the size of that DMS instance now you've running in the cloud the
database tuning that you had on Prem may not have been appropriate for running on modern cloud infrastructure with SSD
based storage and all those types of things so you might need to re-evaluate how you're doing your database tuning and look at those things also resize the
instances write what you let's say you had a seven-year-old piece of hardware with 16 cores and you did the same thing
in AWS well that's a hell of a lot more performance now than what you had on Prem so you can probably resize some of
that down as well and then use things like ec2 and RDS both support stop and
start so this means for development environments that you can turn them off on the weekend bring them back up during the beginning of the week or even at
night you can turn them off and then bring them back on at the start of the day again and that's a huge cost saving
mechanism for you right there and then one of the big ones at the bottom there is perform your H a and D are operations
as you plan to but trying to look at taking advantage of the many services that we have
so in RDS we actually support manual detection of failures and sorry automatic detection of failures and
failover so that you can not have to worry when something goes wrong that
something is going to failover to another data center and the application is going to keep running so do look at
leveraging some of our services instead of doing that the manual way that you would have on Prem in a traditional

the other thing I just want to really drum into you remember that for the migration process there are two tools
and two steps so the first one in this case we're looking at migrating an Oracle database to Amazon Arora so what
we're gonna do is create a brand new Amazon or a database and then we're gonna use the schema conversion tool as
the first step to take the schema migrate that change the table definitions change the data types and

schema conversion tool in that environment now ready on Amazon Aurora so at that point when you're happy with
the schema you've got no data at all in there everything's ready stored procedures triggers everything's good to

guess what it does it actually does create tables and it will create primary keys but it won't bring across the core

half-baked solution so please remember there's one thing you remember from this session to use both tools when you're

migrating from Oracle to Aurora Postgres so what we tend to find is that when you're
looking at migrating away from an Oracle database the best fit in the open source world is Postgres it has a similar

to Oracle's PLC equal so we do find that you'll get conversion rates as I mentioned of about 90% and when you're
going from Oracle to Postgres when you go oracle to my sequel it can be down 40% 50% area we're trying to get better
at that but fundamentally Postgres is richer it has more features and more capabilities that closely match what
Oracle has so this playbook will actually take you through all of the steps of what you want to do so remember

transportation logistics company so they do GPS monitoring or transport and those
